title: Pork noodle soup
text:
This is a go-to meal for us. Very easy to make with things mostly on hand and exceedingly delicious.
8 servings



Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking. Recipe by Alison Roman.

1 pound ground pork
3-6 cloves of garlic, thinly sliced (optional)
red pepper flakes, to taste
6-12 cups chicken broth
1/4 cup soy sauce, (approx)
a few dashes fish sauce (optional)
1/2 bunch cilantro
large bunch spinach, yu choy, bok choy, rapini, swiss chard, or similar
1 inch piece ginger
6oz dried rice noodles
2 medium onions




Heat a few tablespoons of oil in a large pot. If using the garlic, fry for about a minute. Watch carefully because it burns quickly. Going for a tan-ish colour. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Add the pork and brown. Break it up as much as possible. Bring a pot of water to a boil for the rice noodles.
Add the chicken stock. Top up with water until you have as much as you’ll want. I like it more brothy, so I end up with about 3 quarts total. Add the soy sauce and fish sauce, if using.
Check noodles, cook until done. Drain, rinse, and set aside.
Bring soup to a simmer, taste for seasoning (it should be reasonably salty, like instant ramen) and cook about 10 minutes. Meanwhile, slice the onions into very thin half-moons and chop the greens into bite-sized pieces. Peel and chop the ginger.
Add 3/4 of the onion, the greens and the ginger to the pot and cook until the greens are done (5-10 minutes depending on the stalks). Chop the cilantro.
Assemble: put noodles in a bowl. Add soup. Garnish with remaining raw onion, cilantro, and garlic. Add more soy sauce, fish sauce, or sriracha if you like.

title: Faust’s Pact
text:
This was a favourite cocktail among my graduate school friends. We first tried it at a now-closed bar called Embury near the Strip District in Pittsburgh.

The bartender moved to Meat & Potatoes, and we kept ordering it (off menu) on occasional trips downtown (conveniently located across from Heinz Hall and the PSO). He eventually gave us the broad outlines of the recipe. It’s basically a Daiquiri made with gin, but made extra spicy, herbaceous, and delicious.
After reading through Dave Arnold’s Liquid Intelligence, and with a big birthday approaching, I decided to try the “blender muddle”, to see if it would work as a batched cocktail to serve at a party (individual drinks would be far too much time).
The blender muddle will only work if you make at least 2 (possibly 4) drinks at once. You need the blades of the blender completely submerged in the alcohol to prevent the basil from turning brown. The result is neon green, and looks awesome. Leave out the bitters if you do this. Otherwise the neon green will become dirt brown.
Recipe for 1 drink


60 ml gin
30 ml lemon juice
20 ml 50/50 simple syrup
3-4 dashes Angostura bitters (omit if blender muddling)
2-3 1/2 inch slices of jalapeño
1/2 inch knob of ginger, peeled
5 basil leaves
Ground cayenne pepper



Combine gin, jalapeño, ginger, and basil in the bottom of a blender. Make sure the blades (and all the solids) are completely covered. If you are planning to serve immediately, you can add the lemon juice. Blend for 5-10 seconds until pureed.
Combine blender contents with simple syrup, bitters, and lemon juice in a cocktail shaker. Add lots of ice and shake for 10-15 seconds.
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a bit of cayenne pepper if desired.

title: Roast pork sandwich
text:
This is super tasty and based on the Philly roast pork sandwich from Leah Colins.
Everything can be prepared completely in advance, but the pork needs at least a day total in the fridge, so it’s a 2 day project. When spread out, it assembles quickly, and each step is mostly unsupervised.


For the pork

3 lbs boneless pork shoulder
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 Tbsp (18g) kosher salt; for table salt use half as much by volume
1 tsp ground black pepper
1 Tbsp minced fresh rosemary, or dried
1 Tbsp minced fresh thyme, or dried
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes
2 Tbsp olive oil
1 medium yellow onion, halved and thinly sliced
2 cups chicken stock

For the sandwich

3 Tbsp olive oil
1 pound broccoli rabe
salt and black pepper
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 pinch red pepper flakes
sliced pickled hot peppers
crusty long white sandwich rolls
provolone cheese


For the pork, day 1

In a bowl, combine garlic, salt, pepper, thyme, rosemary, and red pepper flakes. Cut 1 inch cross-hatches into the fat-cap of the pork. Place pork on a double layer of plastic wrap, and coat all exposed sides with the spice mixture. Tie with kitchen twine so that it is shaped like a brick. Wrap tightly with the plastic and refrigerate for 12–24 hours.
Heat oven to 325ºF. In a dutch oven, heat oil over medium and add the onions. Cook until soft but not browned, about 5 minutes. Add pork on top of the onions, fat side up. Add chicken stock, cover, and place in the oven. Cook for about two hours, until the internal temperature reaches 180ºF. Remove the pork from the oven, let rest for 1 hour, then transfer to the refrigerator for at least 2 hours. Save jus for later.

Assembly

Heat a skillet over medium, add oil and broccoli rabe, salt and pepper. Cook about 5 minutes, then add garlic. If the pan is too dry, add a little water to loosen.
Meanwhile, slice the pork very thinly. Combine the amount you will use with some of the jus. Save the rest for later. Cover and microwave until heated through.
Slice rolls if needed, add provolone and broil briefly until bubly.
Place pork, broccoli rabe, and sliced peppers on the sandwich and serve with a few spponfuls of jus.

title: Asparagus chicken turmeric stir fry
text:
This is an easy, but flavourful stir fry that I make regularly.
It only takes about 20 minutes to make. I usually serve it with rice and sauteed greens (cooked with a 50/50 mixture of soy sauce and water).



Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking, Ali Slagle

1 lb asparagus
2 Tbsp flour or cornstarch
1 Tbsp ground turmeric
salt to taste
1 Tbsp honey
1 Tbsp ground black pepper (or more)
1 lb boneless, skinless chicken thighs or breasts or turkey or tofu
3 Tbsp neutral oil



Trim bottoms of asparagus and cut into bitesize pieces.
Combine flour or cornstarch, turmeric, and a pinch of salt in a bowl large enough to hold the chicken.
Combine honey, black pepper and 1/4 cup water in a small bowl.
Cut protein into bitesize pieces. Add to flour mixture and toss to coat.
Add oil to the pan and heat over medium. Once the oil shimmers, add chicken and cook until browned all over, about 5 minutes, stirring to keep pieces distinct. Add asparagus and cook for 2-3 minutes until brighter in colour, but still crispy.
Add honey mixture to the pan, scraping up any stuck-on chicken bits. Add additional water if needed. It should thicken into a sauce in about 2 minutes.
Serve with steamed white rice.

title: Speedy tomato soup
text:
This is a very fast homemade tomato soup.
It only takes about 20 minutes to make, and uses only pantry staples. Serve with grilled cheese.



Lightly adapted from: Serious Eats

olive oil
1/2 a small onion, diced
1 clove garlic, minced
28oz whole tomatoes (higher quality is better…)
1-2 cups stock or water
crushed red pepper
oregano
1 tsp Worchestershire sauce or a few anchovies or soy sauce or all
1 slice bread
salt to taste



Saute the onion in the olive oil on low until it softens, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic for 30 seconds more.
Add the tomatoes, stock, and spices to taste. Heat to a simmer.
Add the Worchestershire sauce and other umami components to taste.
Add the bread, torn into small pieces.
Blend the whole thing with an imersion blender, salt to taste, and serve.

title: Green pasta
text:
Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne.




1 lb short-cut pasta (such as rigatoni, campanelle or fusilli)
8 ounces sugar snap peas
2 cups frozen sweet peas
3 packed cups (4 oz) baby spinach
2 packed cups basil leaves, plus more for serving
2 tablespoons white miso
1 garlic clove, crushed
Zest and juice from 1 lemon
1/2 cup olive oil
Parmesan (or other firm salty cheese, such as feta or aged Gouda)



Make the noodles according to package directions. About 30 seconds before they are done, add both types of peas.
Meanwhile, add spinach, basil, miso, garlic, and lemon zest and juice to a blender. Once mostly blended, slowly drizzle oil until incorporated. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Drain noodles and peas and mix with sauce. Serve with grated or sliced cheese.

title: Miso-Sesame Vinaigrette
text:
Delicious on many things.

Typical usage is on a salad of lettuce; crunchy stuff like celery, carrots, radish, cucumber; pulled rotisserie chicken; and herbs like cilantro, parsley, mint, scallions, or a mix.
Garnish with fried shallots or French-fried onions or pumpkin seeds or avocado.
Also, makes a great coleslaw: combine coleslaw mix with dressing and salted peanuts.
makes approx. 2 cups



Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking. Recipe by J. Kenji Lopez-Alt.
All measurements approximate.

8 Tbsp vineger, usually split 50/50 wine vinegar and balsamic or Shiaoxing
2 Tbsp Miso
1 shallot,
3 garlic cloves
2 Tbsp brown sugar
3/4 cup oil (not olive)
4 Tbsp sesame oil
White and/or Black sesame seeds



Chop shallot and smash garlic.
Throw shallot, garlic, miso, vinegar, and sugar in a blender. Blend until combined.
Slowly add oil (not sesame) to blender while it runs. If hard to open the blender without splattering everywhere, then do it in thirds.
Stir in sesame oil and sesame seeds

Store in an air-tight container in the fridge for up to a month.

title: Instant pot beef stew
text:
This is pretty close to a one pot meal. Best served with a green salad or green vegetable with viniagrette and baguette.
8 servings



Adapted from: Serious Eats recipe by J. Kenji López-Alt

4 oz pork belly or thick sliced bacon, cut into lardons
2.5 pounds chuck roast, brisket, or other stew beef
6 oz crimini mushrooms
1 pkg pearl onions, 15-20
5 carrots
3 stalks celery
1 onion
3 cups chicken stock
3 packets gelatin
1 small can tomato paste
1 Tbsp soy sauce
2 tsp fish sauce or 5 anchovies
2 bay leaves
1 tsp dried thyme or 3 sprigs fresh
3 cloves of garlic, unpeeled
1/2 cup sherry, dry vermouth, brandy, or wine
4 T flour
1 pound potatoes, peeled
1.5 cups frozen peas



Set the pressure cooker to Saute (on low), and render the pork or bacon. You may need to add a little water to help the rendering. Remove to a plate, leaving 2 T or so of rendered fat.
Meanwhile, bring a pot of water to a boil. Add the pearl onions, and boil about 30 seconds. This will make them easy to peel quickly. Remove, drain, and let cool until you can peel them. You can trim the tops, but be careful with the bottoms. Keeping the bottom will help them stay whole later.
Cut beef into 2-3 large “steaks”. Season on both sides with salt and pepper. Add to the pressure cooker, increase to medium, and sear on both sides. About 5-10 minutes per side. Remove to the same plate as the pork.
Add quartered mushrooms to the cooker until browned. Remove to a different plate. Add the peeled pearl onions to the cooker until browned. Remove to the same plate as the mushrooms.
Cut the onion in half from pole to pole, trim the root and peel. Cut 2 carrots in half long ways. Cut the celery and carrots into 3-4 inch pieces. Add all of these and the garlic to the cooker and sear on 1-2 sides.
Combine the tomato paste, chicken stock, soy sauce, fish sauce, and gelatin in a container and whisk to blend.
Cut the beef into chunks. Toss with the flour.
When the large vegetables are seared, add the liquor or wine and scrape to deglaze all the stuck bits. Allow to reduce by half (about 2-3 minutes).
Add the beef, pork, and the stock mix to the cooker. Add the bay leaves and thyme. Seal the cooker and cook on high pressure for 30 minutes. Rapidly release steam.
Meanwhile cut the remaining carrots and potatoes into chunks.
Open the cooker. Remove all the vegetables (which are now flavourless) and discard. Taste the liquid and adjust seasoning.
Add the potatoes, carrots, mushrooms and pearl onions. Seal the cooker and cook on high for 15 minutes. The rapidly release the steam.
Add the peas and stir. Taste again for seasoning. Serve immediately or let cool and refrigerate for a day before serving.

title: Caldo verde
text:
I make this soup very frequently. It’s easy, and doesn’t require stock.
I prefer the version with ground sausage rather than smoked+sliced. Most of the time, I omit the tomatoes.


1lb bulk sausage. Ideally something spicy and Portuguese or Spanish (linguica). Hot Italian works well. Alternatively, one of the smoked (cooked) sausages like kielbasa (again, better if spicy), sliced into half-moons.
1 large onion, diced
2 bunches kale (I prefer Lacinto) or collard greens
3-4 yukon gold potatoes,
1/2 can diced tomatoes (optional)



Add some oil to a large pot and brown the sausage. If bulk, break it up after it starts to brown. If using cooked sausage, flip it around a bit to get some color. Remove the slices if using, leave the bulk.
If the pan is dry, add a little more oil. Add the onion and cook until soft.
Meanwhile, peel and dice the potatoes.
Add the potatoes, then 2–3 quarts of water.
Slice the greens into thin ribbons and add to the pot. Add the tomatoes and their juices if using. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for about 20 minutes, when the potatoes should be completely cooked and beginning to fall apart.
Using a potato masher, smash the potatoes in the soup, as desired.
If you used cooked sausage, add it back to the pot, and heat through.

Serve with crusty bread and wine.

title: Pork noodles
text:
This is a mashup of 2 different recipes: pad kee mao and ginger pork noodles.



Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.




12 oz noodles, cooked to pkg directions (spaghetti, wide Thai noodles, rice noodles, etc.)
2 Tbs oyster sauce
3 Tbs soy sauce
1 Tbs fish sauce
2 Tbs Chianking black vinegar or balsamic vinegar
3 Thai chiles or 1 jalapeño
1 oz slivered ginger
3 garlic cloves, sliced
3 Tbs vegetable oil
8 oz ground pork
12 oz baby bok choy or gai lan or spinach (not baby), cut into bite size pieces.
1 cup Thai basil or a mix of sliced scallions and cilantro



Make the noodles.
Prepare the sauce. Mix together the oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce, and vinegar.
Heat a large pan or wok to medium and add the vegetable oil. Cook pork until lightly browned.
Meanwhile, mix the noodles with the sauce in a large bowl.
Add the greens (stems first if they are sturdy) and cook until wilted.
Add the noodles and reheat. Be careful not to break them too much. Add the basil, remove from heat, dump back into the bowl, mix a bit more, and serve.

title: No knead sourdough
text:
This entire recipe takes about 3 days, from start to finish. But very little active time. Since the middle of the pandemic, I’ve been baking this once a week. Other than baguettes, we rarely buy bread anymore. And this costs almost nothing.







Sourdough starter
Whole wheat flour
All purpose flour
Salt
Enameled cast-iron Dutch oven (with a lid)
Corn meal



Day 1 (8-12 hours start to finish, most inactive)

Remove starter from fridge. Let sit for about 1 hour, to come to room temperature. (You don’t HAVE to let it sit, but I find it reduces the next resting step.)
Feed the starter. Add 110g flour and 110g water. Stir vigorously. Cover. Place in a warm place until it at least doubles in volume, reaching the top of the jar. [Note: If the house is cool, I use the oven with the light on. It takes about 8 hours. On the counter takes 8 or so. If you leave it too long, it will either make a huge mess as it escapes the jar, or will consume all the flour you just added and start deflating.]
Combine 220g fed/ripe starter with 600g flour, 400g water, and 18g salt in a large bowl. (I use a large, 500g stainless steel mixing bowl that has an air tight plastic lid.) Don’t forget the salt. I use 300/300 regular to whole wheat flour, but feel free to experiment. I found more WW to be too dry and crumbly. Mix well, cover, and let sit on the counter for an hour. You should have about 80-100g starter left. Put that back in the fridge. (If less, add equal parts flour and water until you do)
Pick up one corner of the dough, pull it out and up, and fold it over the top of the dough. You can be aggressive, but you won’t be pulling so hard that your hand is much above the bowl. Work your way around the dough for about a minute. Recover. And let sit 1 hour.
Repeat step 4 twice more. The dough should start too feel more uniform and less sticky as you go. After your third round, put the covered bowl in the fridge.
Leave it in the fridge for at least 24 hours and up to 4 days. Longer seems to be better, but only marginally.



Day 3 (4 hours, about 30 minutes of active time)

Remove dough from fridge. Let rest in the bowl for an hour.
Cover a clean bit of counter with a dusting of flour. (I now just use the inverted plastic bowl lid, and don’t use any flour, to be less messy.) Turn dough onto counter and shape into a ball. Cover with a towel and let rise for 1-2 hours. Currently, for me, an hour is enough since the starter is quite active. It should look a bit bigger and may flatten out a bit. About 30 minutes before it’s done, place a covered Dutch oven in the bottom third of the oven and preheat to 425 degrees.
Prepare to bake. Set up a place near the dough to put the hot Dutch oven and its lid. When the oven is done preheating, remove the Dutch oven, and close the oven door. Remove the lid and spread some corn meal on the bottom to keep the bread from sticking. Quickly make 1-3 slashes across the top of the bread with a sharp knife or a bread knife, and drop it into the Dutch oven, slashes up. Put the lid back on, and put it in the oven.
Bake for 15 minutes and then remove the lid.
Bake another 35 minutes. You’re looking for a nice brown top, and a hollow sound. Or if you have an instant thermometer, 209 degrees in the coldest part.
Remove from oven, take the bread out of the Dutch oven, and cool on a rack.



Background for making a starter

Creating a starter
My starter lives in the fridge in a lidded 20oz glass jar. You could get some from a neighbour who bakes sourdough. I made it with bakers yeast from the Whole Foods Bakery (had no friends): ~20g yeast + 100g water + 100g flour. You could also use dry yeast in a packet, or nothing. But it will take more rounds of feeding to get vigorous enough. Basically, repeat steps 1 and 2 from Day 1 instructions a few times. That is: (1) Feed it 100g flour + 100g water, (2) stir vigorously, (3) let it rest for a while and see how long it takes to double in size. If it isn’t doubled after 12 hours, then remove about half. Throw the rest in the fridge for a few days. Repeat 2-3 times. What you’re looking for is for it to get to the point that it will double in size in 8 hours or less if left out. If it takes longer, then the starter isn’t yet ready for baking bread.


Maintaining the starter
It needs to be fed about once a week. Less frequently, it gets too slack to leaven bread on one feeding. So I try to bake once a week. Otherwise, just feed it by removing about 200g and replacing with 100g each flour and water. It will likely be fine up to two weeks. Any longer, you’ll need to do the feeding process a few times. If you forget it for a month, it might start to look gross. It’s probably fine and can be rescued, but you may not want to.

title: Indonesian chicken noodle soup
text:
Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking, James Oseland and Julia Moskin

12 cups chicken stock
1 lb chicken, breasts or thighs
3 cloves of garlic
1 inch piece ginger
3 shallots or 1/3 of an onion (about 4 oz)
1 tsp black peppercorns
1 1/2 tsp coriander seeds
2 tsp cumin seeds
1 1/2 tsp ground turmeric
2 stalks lemon grass (optional)
6oz dried rice noodles
1/2 bunch cilantro or Thai basil or mixed herbs
fried shallots
limes
chili paste
4 hard boiled eggs
steamed bok choy or other greens



Grind peppercorns, coriander, cumin, turmeric, garlic, ginger, and shallot (or onion) in a small food processor or mortar and pestle. Add a little water if needed.
Heat chicken stock in a large pot, ideally one with a steamer insert. Add the raw chicken and the lemon grass. Cook about 20-30 minutes until chicken is done.
During the last 10 minutes or so, steam the bok choy or other greens. If you don’t have a steamer insert, you can just add them to the soup at the end, or steam separately.
Remove chicken and shred. Discard lemon grass.
Meanwhile, heat a few tablespoons of oil in a small pan. Add the spice paste and fry for a few minutes.
Bring a pot of water to boil and cook noodles according to the package directions. Drain and rinse.
Add the spice paste to the soup.
Assemble: put noodles in a bowl. Add soup, shredded chicken, a boiled egg, and the greens. Garnish with cilantro and fried shallots. Serve with lime and/or chili paste.

title: Vegetable korma
text:
Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.





Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking, Zainab Shah

1/4 cup coconut oil or vegatable oil
1 onion, finely chopped
2 tsp black mustard seeds
1 tsp grated ginger
1 tsp grated garlic
3 Thai chiles or 1 jalapeño sliced
ground black pepper to taste
salt to taste
1 tsp red chile powder or hot paprika or more to taste
1/2 tsp turmeric
3 medium tomatoes, chopped
2 Tbsp cashew or peanut butter
1.5 lbs frozen (not thawed) mixed vegatables (I use “stir fry mix”)
1 (13.5-ounce) can coconut milk
1 teaspoon garam masala or more to taste
chopped cilantro



Heat oil in a dutch oven or large pot over medium. When hot, onion and saute about 5 minutes (browning or not as desired). Add mustard seeds, garlic, and ginger, and continue to saute for 1 minute.
Stir in spices, tomatoes and cashew butter, continue to cook until the tomatoes break down, about 5 minutes.
Add vegatables and coconut milk. Cook for 8-10 minutes.
Add garam masala and cilantro. Serve with rice or naan and Indian pickles.

title: Indian butter tofu and cauliflower
text:
Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.





Lightly adapted from: NYT Cooking, Sarah Copeland

juice of 1 lemon
1 Tbsp ground cumin
1 Tbsp ground turmeric
500g extra-firm tofu, cut into 1 inch cubes
1/2 head cauliflower, separated into florets
4-6 oz butter or ghee
1 large onion, diced
4 cloves garlic, minced
1 inch piece ginger, minced
28oz can whole tomatoes
cayenne pepper
garam masala
1 can coconut milk
chopped cilantro or scallions



Combine lemon juice, cumin, turmeric and 1–2 Tbsp of water in a large bowl that will hold the tofu and cauliflower. Mix to form a slurry. Add tofu and cauliflower and toss to marinate.
Heat butter or ghee over medium-low in a large lidded pot. Add onions and saute for 5 minutes, until they are beginning to brown.
Add garlic and ginger and saute briefly.
Add the tomatoes, the garam masala, and the cayenne pepper. I use about 2T of the garam masala and a reasonable amount of cayenne, but both should be to taste. Break up the tomatoes a bit, and simmer, covered for about 10 minutes.
Blend the tomatoes with an imersion blender. Add the coconut milk and the tofu+cauliflower mixture. Stir gently. Cover and simmer 5-10 minutes, until the cauliflower is cooked to your desired texture.

Serve with rice or naan.

title: Miso soup
text:
This is really a “template” for miso soup. All listed ingredients are optional except the soup base. I’ll usually make about 6-8 cups of broth for the 3-4 meals. I try to keep most ingredients “around” so I can throw this together if I don’t have time / ideas for dinner.



The instant dashi contains MSG. It doesn’t bother most people, but will put my mother in the hospital.

Soup base

miso paste
Instant Dashi, I use Ajinomoto HonDashi



Ingredients template

Something leafy (spinach, seaweed, parsley, etc.)
Some stems (fennel, celery, asparagus, green beans, etc.)
Some roots (carrot, daikon, radish, celery root, potato?)
Protein (mushrooms, tofu, clams, rotisserie chicken, etc.)



Seasonings (all optional)

soy sauce
sesame oil
sesame seeds
anything else



Make the soup base. Bring water to a simmer. Remove about 1/2 cup to mix with the miso paste. Add the instant dashi powder (1 tsp per 2 cups water).
You’ll need about 1 Tbsp miso paste per 2 cups of liquid. Add it to the removed liquid and stir until incorporated. If your paste is old, it helps to force it through a fine strainer. Or you could use a small blender or a miso muddler. Mix back into the simmering stock.
Add all ingredients. You want at least one thing from each category. They should all cook pretty quickly. Taste for saltiness, and add salt or soy sauce.
